James Palmer]] | successor = [[Aubin-Edmond Arsenault]] | term_start = December 2, 1911 | term_end = June 21, 1917 | birth_date = {{birth date|1863|05|19}} | birth_place = Harrington, Prince Edward Island | death_date = {{death date and age|1947|01|7|1863|05|19}} | death_place = | nationality = | spouse = | party = [[Prince Edward Island Progressive Conservative Party|Conservative]] | otherparty = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | religion = | cabinet = }} '''John Alexander Mathieson''' (May 19, 1863 – January 7, 1947) was a [[Prince Edward Island]] politician and jurist, the [[List of premiers of Prince Edward Island|12th]] [[Premier of Prince Edward Island|Premier]]. Mathieson was born in [[Harrington, Prince Edward Island|Harrington]] and was a graduate of [[Prince of Wales College]]. He was a schoolmaster and lawyer before entering politics with his election to the province's [[legislature]] as a [[PEI Conservative Party|Conservative]] in 1900. Mathieson sat on the [[parliamentary opposition|opposition]] benches becoming [[Leader of the Opposition (PEI)|leader of the opposition]] and the Conservative Party in 1903. In December 1911, the Liberal government resigned when [[Premier]] [[H. James Palmer]] was defeated in a [[by-election]] which also caused the governing [[PEI Liberal Party|Liberals]] to lose their [[majority government|majority]] in the legislature. The [[lieutenant-governor]] asked Mathieson as leader of the opposition to form a government, which he did, going on to win a mandate in the 1912 general election. Mathieson's government pressed the federal government to fulfill the terms on which Prince Edward Island joined [[Canadian confederation]] in 1873. He succeeded in persuading Ottawa to provide an improved annual subsidy to the province and, in 1915, Ottawa announced the creation of a year round ferry service to connect the island to the mainland. The ferries began operating between PEI and [[New Brunswick]] in 1917. The province was also at risk of losing representation in the [[Canadian House of Commons]] due to population shifts. PEI had six [[Member of Parliament|MP]]s when it joined confederation in 1873, this was reduced to four and was to be cut further as a result of the 1911 census. Mathieson persuaded the federal government to agree to an amendment to the [[British North America Act]] guaranteeing the province a minimum of four MPs in perpetuity.
